newsitem.title: LATVIA: BALTICS-LITHUANIA BROKERS SLOW PAN-BALTIC BOURSE-LATVIA.
newsitem.headline: BALTICS-LITHUANIA BROKERS SLOW PAN-BALTIC BOURSE-LATVIA.

text.p: The Latvian central depository said on Wednesday that pressure from Lithuanian brokers on their central depository was preventing a pan-Baltic equities market from being formed.

Latvia and Estonia signed a co-operation agreement earlier this year allowing investors to keep the other countries' shares in an account in their home country and carry out settlements in their home country as well.
Latvia and Estonia want to sign a similar agreement with Lithuania.

"The Lithuanian depository is holding back from joining (the two other Baltic states' agreement) following recommendations from their financial intermediaries," Martinsh Rikshe, president of the depositary, told a news conference.
"They are afraid of losing profit if Estonian or Latvian players enter the market," Rikshe added.
"The Lithuanian depository supports such a step in principle but is not ready because of the pressure from market members," Rikshe said.
This was preventing the creation of an infrastructure for a common Baltic equities market, he added.
"Many foreign institutions, which expressed their satisfaction about the Estonian and Latvian agreement, are now puzzled about the situation with Lithuania," Rikshe said.
Many foreign investors view the Baltic as a single unit and would like to have use one of the national bourses as gateway to the rest of the region's financial markets.
